title.narrative: Shoulder to Shoulder - Jordan Refugee and Vulnerable Host Communities Project

description.narrative: Implementation of community level quick impact projects comprising of rehabilitation of public infrastructure, support to local councils and active engagement of community members through social cohesion events.

name.narrative: Locally in neighbourhoods of 1) al Hashmi Shmali; 2) Sweileh; 3) Abu Nusser; 4) Tareq; 5) Tla al’Ali; 6) Shafra Badran; 7) Al Rasheed.

title.narrative: Final Report - Shoulder to Shoulder Project
Annual Report - Shoulder to Shoulder
Outcome 1: Refugees and vulnerable host communities are better protected against violence and abuse (1.1b)

description.narrative:
Outcome indicator 1.1: % of target community surveyed who report positive perception of safety and security messaging | Target = 70% | Achieved = 94% (93% men; 94% women; 93% refugees; 96% host community). Participants in community Initiatives noted that the Community Police personnel - trained by Siren and Siren-trained PSD trainers had a marked difference in their attitude towards and engagement with the target community. They were more respectful compared to personnel from other departments.
Outcome indicator 1.2: # of individuals who have been reached through improved communication and media outputs | Baseline = 3,440 | Achieved = 111,898 reached through videos and posts on PSD Facebook (PSD website is too new for data. Disaggregation by sex or nationality not possible given communication platforms).
Outcome indicator 1.3: # of Community Police Hub personnel who report greater coordination at HQ and between HQ and local field teams as a result of project activities | Achieved = According to the PSD Head of the Community Police (interviewed as part of the end of project evaluation) the refurbishment of the multi-purpose hall and offices in North Amman and PSD headquarters provided a marked improvement in the quality and availability of space. Previously at PSD HQ some officers had to work from a different building which made effective coordination difficult. The better equipped and the more practical spaces are now being used by the HQ team to coordinate activities with local Community Police teams and LSC members.

title.narrative: Final Report
Perception of safety and security in three pilot sites
Outcome 2: Expanded and improved integrated basic service delivery that includes both refugees and host communities (1.2a)

description.narrative:
Outcome indicator 2.1: % members of vulnerable groups who see community initiatives as responding to their needs | Target = 80% of those surveyed | Achieved = 98% (Respondents were 36% men, 62% women, 10% refugees, 88% host community, 97% youth).
Outcome indicator 2.2: PSD assessment of their ability to engage with community members on community-identified safety concerns (qualitative) | Achieved = Interviews with PSD indicated increased ability to engage with community members on community-identified safety concerns. A longitudinal study of the community police trainers (over the duration of the project) identified a change in perception of the core group of community police trainers and their relationships with Local Security Council members. At the beginning of the project they were worried about engaging with the LSCs on account of their social status and background. This changed after they had been trained to – and went on to give - trainings to them due to increased confidence in their new skills, abilities and experience. Feedback from workshops between the community police and CBOs also identifies increased confidence in the former’s ability to engage with community members: “In the training of the CBOS, there were two or three people who worked on the initiatives individually, now everyone is working all together as one hand, now they know what the initiative is and how they do it from A to Z.” (Interview, PSD Officer North Amman).

title.narrative: Final Report

description.narrative: Final Report

title.narrative: % members of vulnerable groups who see community initiatives as responding to their needs
PSD assessment of their ability to engage with community members on community-identified safety concerns (qualitative)

actual.value: Interviews with PSD indicated increased ability to engage with community members on community-identified safety concerns. A longitudinal study of the community police trainers (over the duration of the project) identified a change in perception of the core group of community police trainers and their relationships with Local Security Council members. At the beginning of the project they were worried about engaging with the LSCs on account of their social status and background. This changed after they had been trained to – and went on to give - trainings to them due to increased confidence in their new skills, abilities and experience. Feedback from workshops between the community police and CBOs also identifies increased confidence in the former’s ability to engage with community members: “In the training of the CBOS, there were two or three people who worked on the initiatives individually, now everyone is working all together as one hand, now they know what the initiative is and how they do it from A to Z.” (Interview, PSD Officer North Amman).

title.narrative: Output 1.1: Greater capacity of the Community Police team at the Hub to document, analyse and disseminate best practice and lessons learn about community policing

description.narrative:
Output indicator 1.1.1: # of Community Police personnel the Hub premises provides for | Target = 20 (18 men and 2 women). | Achieved = 30 (20 men and 10 women). This achievement results from the support and buy-in of the new Director of the newly renamed Media and Community Policing Directorate who - welcoming the refurbishment to a dedicated space for the HQ Community Policing Team - decided to allocate more space than planned at PSD Headquarters in order to ensure that Community Policing Team were able to join their media colleagues to support enhanced promotion of community safety. Additionally, the inclusion of an office for women police facilitated more women being assigned directly to the department.
Output indicator 1.1.2: # of communication and media segments produced increasing visibility of and access to personnel, mission and services offered | Target = 5 | Achieved = 15 This includes PSD coverage of S2S sponsored community initiatives, getting key messages out to larger sections of the population. It also includes live call-in sessions on the PSD Amen FM (telecasted on YouTube and Facebook), again sponsored through the S2S project. Key messages were provided on community safety issues, including a segment on cybercrime which the Community Police focused on after learning that a third of the Amman population were concerned with cybercrime, following the S2S funded public perception survey into community safety.
Output indicator 1.1.3: # of community police trainers with increased ability to train community police field staff and LSC members in Problem Solving, Communication Skills, Creative thinking and Conflict Management | Target = 6 | Achieved = 6

title.narrative: Final Report

description.narrative: Final Report

title.narrative: # of Community Police personnel the Hub premises provides for
# of community police trainers with increased ability to train community police field staff and LSC members in Problem Solving, Communication Skills, Creative thinking and Conflict Management
Output 2.1: Increased capacity of local community police and security council members to engage with community members.

description.narrative:
Output indicator 2.1.1: # of spaces refurbished facilitating engagement between community police and community members | Target = 3 | Achieved = 3 (multi-purpose hall in North Amman, office space in North Amman for the Community Police Team, and office space in South Amman for the Community Police Team.)
Output indicator 2.1.2: # of individuals (PSD; LSC members; Community) trained/coached to engage on community safety issues | Target = 50 | Achieved = 129 (91 men; 38 women). This figure does not only represent an output, but also an outcome. The vast majority of those trained were not trained by Siren directly, but by the PSD trainers that Siren had previously trained. The PSD trainers used their new skills, ability and increased confidence to go on to train others including community groups that they had previously faced challenges engaging with. Those trained included local community police personnel, members of the Local Security Councils, and members of local CBOs.
Output indicator 2.1.3: # trainees who score 75% demonstrating understanding of need to include voices of diverse communities | Target = 40 | Achieved = 38 (31 men and 7 women)

title.narrative: Final report
% members of vulnerable groups who see community initiatives as responding to their needs
Output 2.2: Increased capacity of the PSD to implement community safety initiatives with and for vulnerable community members.

description.narrative:
Output indicator 2.2.1: # of crisis impacted individuals benefiting from each initiative | Target = 20,500 direct and indirect beneficiaries (4,100 youth across 10 sites who go on to work with 4 other people each) | Achieved = 3,940 - direct (930 men; 1,548 women; 1,264 refugees, 2,674 host community; 2,404 youth). 15,760 - indirect.
Output indicator 2.2.2: # initiatives planned with input from diverse voices | Target = 5 | Achieved = 5/5 initiatives 2x Conscious Student initiatives; 2 x Conscious Youth initiatives; One Body initiative; Additionally, graduates from the Conscious Youth initiatives took part in environment and road safety campaigns with the PSD and produced videos and social media content dealing with cybercrime and bullying online.

title.narrative: Final Report

description.narrative: Final Report

target.value: Head of PSD Community Police Department and staff

actual.value: According to the PSD Head of the Community Police (interviewed as part of the end of project evaluation) the refurbishment of the multi-purpose hall and offices in North Amman and PSD headquarters provided a marked improvement in the quality and availability of space. Previously at PSD HQ some officers had to work from a different building which made effective coordination difficult. The better equipped and the more practical spaces are now being used by the HQ team to coordinate activities with local Community Police teams and LSC members.

title.narrative: # of individuals who have been reached through improved communication and media outputs
